title: What Does the $P$-value Tell Us?
question_text:
Market researchers know that background music can influence the mood and purchasing behavior of customers. One study in a supermarket in Syracuse compared three treatments: no music, smooth jazz music, and upbeat reggae music.
Under each condition, the researchers recorded the number of bottles of white, red, and other wine purchased. Here is the two-way table that summarizes the data.
Type of Music None Jazz Reggae Total
White $16$ $13$ $20$ $49$
Red $10$ $21$ $12$ $43$
Other $20$ $9$ $14$ $43$
To determine if there an association between the type of wine purchased and the type of music playing, the researchers run an appropriate test and calculate a $P$-value of $0.032$. What is the correct interpretation of this $P$-value?
tables:
Type of MusicNoneJazzReggaeTotal
White$16$$13$$20$$49$
Red$10$$21$$12$$43$
Other$20$$9$$14$$43$

choices.text: Given the results of the study, the probability of a shopper purchasing red wine is $0.032$.
Given the results of the study, the probability of a shopper purchasing any wine is $0.032$.
Given that type of music playing is not associated with type of wine purchased, the probability of getting a value of $\chi^2$ at least as large as the one from this study is $0.032$.
Given that type of music playing is associated with type of wine purchased, the probability of getting a value of $\chi^2$ at least as large as the one from this study is $0.032$.
Given that type of music playing is not associated with type of wine purchased, the probability of getting a value of $\chi^2$ like the one from this study is $0.032$.
